div.p: In general, use the latest available stable (non-alpha) version of Erlang.
The minimum version of Erlang required to run the RabbitMQ server is R12B-3. Certain RabbitMQ configurations require more recent versions:

tr.td: Also needs the Erlang development and runtime tools
Some plugins depend on mochiweb, e.g. the management plugin
Earlier versions do not recognise memory limits.
Earlier versions do not support SSL well.

div.p: If using clustered nodes, all nodes should use the same version of Erlang.

Most current distributions now package Erlang that supports all the above. You can check these specific distributions:
OpenSUSE
Fedora
Macports
Debian
Ubuntu
Fedora EPEL 5 SRPMS
div.h3: How to get a later version

dl.dd: Install the Erlang Windows binary from www.erlang.org/downloads.html
dl.dt: RedHat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) and derived distributions (e.g. CentOS):
dl.dd: The owner of the EPEL Erlang package provides a package repository: (as root) wget -O /etc/yum.repos.d/epel-erlang.repo http://repos.fedorapeople.org/repos/peter/erlang/epel-erlang.repo. Invoking yum install erlang will then install Erlang.

div.p: If you need newer features of Erlang than the package manager for your Linux distribution provides, it may be best to update your distribution.

As a last resort you might build Erlang from source. Be aware that if you do, your package manager can't know that you have done so. You'll therefore need to install RabbitMQ from the generic Unix package, or from source.
If you should need to build Erlang from source, you will need OpenSSL installed on your system.
